4502         return np.log(2.0/np.pi) - sc.log1p(x*x)
4503 
4504     def _cdf(self, x):
4505         return 2.0/np.pi*np.arctan(x)
4506 
4507     def _ppf(self, q):
4508         return np.tan(np.pi/2*q)
4509 
4510     def _sf(self, x):
4511         return 2.0/np.pi * np.arctan2(1, x)
4512 
4513     def _isf(self, p):
4514         return 1.0/np.tan(np.pi*p/2)
4515 
4516     def _stats(self):
4517         return np.inf, np.inf, np.nan, np.nan
4518 
4519     def _entropy(self):
4520         return np.log(2*np.pi)
4521 
4522     @_call_super_mom
4523     @inherit_docstring_from(rv_continuous)
4524     def fit(self, data, *args, **kwds):
4525         if kwds.pop('superfit', False):
4526             return super().fit(data, *args, **kwds)
4527 
4528         data, floc, fscale = _check_fit_input_parameters(self, data,
4529                                                          args, kwds)
4530 
4531         # location is independent from the scale
4532         data_min = np.min(data)
4533         if floc is not None:
4534             if data_min < floc:
4535                 # There are values that are less than the specified loc.
4536                 raise FitDataError("halfcauchy", lower=floc, upper=np.inf)
4537             loc = floc
4538         else:
4539             # if not provided, location MLE is the minimal data point
4540             loc = data_min
4541 
4542         # find scale
4543         def find_scale(loc, data):
4544             shifted_data = data - loc
4545             n = data.size
4546             shifted_data_squared = np.square(shifted_data)
4547 
4548             def fun_to_solve(scale):
4549                 denominator = scale**2 + shifted_data_squared
4550                 return 2 * np.sum(shifted_data_squared/denominator) - n
4551 
4552             small = np.finfo(1.0).tiny**0.5  # avoid underflow
4553             res = root_scalar(fun_to_solve, bracket=(small, np.max(shifted_data)))
4554             return res.root
4555 
4556         if fscale is not None:
4557             scale = fscale
4558         else:
4559             scale = find_scale(loc, data)
4560 
4561         return loc, scale
4562 
4563 
4564 halfcauchy = halfcauchy_gen(a=0.0, name='halfcauchy')
4565 
4566 
4567 class halflogistic_gen(rv_continuous):
4568     r"""A half-logistic continuous random variable. 
4569  
4570     %(before_notes)s 
4571  
4572     Notes 
4573     ----- 
4574     The probability density function for `halflogistic` is: 
4575  
4576     .. math:: 
4577  
4578         f(x) = \frac{ 2 e^{-x} }{ (1+e^{-x})^2 } 
4579              = \frac{1}{2} \text{sech}(x/2)^2 
4580  
4581     for :math:`x \ge 0`. 
4582  
4583     %(after_notes)s 
4584  
4585     References 
4586     ---------- 
4587     .. [1] Asgharzadeh et al (2011). "Comparisons of Methods of Estimation for the 
4588            Half-Logistic Distribution". Selcuk J. Appl. Math. 93-108. 
4589  
4590     %(example)s 
4591  
4592     """
4593     def _shape_info(self):
4594         return []
4595 
4596     def _pdf(self, x):
4597         # halflogistic.pdf(x) = 2 * exp(-x) / (1+exp(-x))**2
4598         #                     = 1/2 * sech(x/2)**2
4599         return np.exp(self._logpdf(x))
4600 
4601     def _logpdf(self, x):
4602         return np.log(2) - x - 2. * sc.log1p(np.exp(-x))
4603 
4604     def _cdf(self, x):
4605         return np.tanh(x/2.0)
4606 
4607     def _ppf(self, q):
4608         return 2*np.arctanh(q)
4609 
4610     def _sf(self, x):
4611         return 2 * sc.expit(-x)
4612 
4613     def _isf(self, q):
4614         return _lazywhere(q < 0.5, (q, ),
4615                           lambda q: -sc.logit(0.5 * q),
4616                           f2=lambda q: 2*np.arctanh(1 - q))
4617 
4618     def _munp(self, n):
4619         if n == 0:
4620             return 1  # otherwise returns NaN
4621         if n == 1:
4622             return 2*np.log(2)
4623         if n == 2:
4624             return np.pi*np.pi/3.0
4625         if n == 3:
4626             return 9*_ZETA3
4627         if n == 4:
4628             return 7*np.pi**4 / 15.0
4629         return 2*(1-pow(2.0, 1-n))*sc.gamma(n+1)*sc.zeta(n, 1)
4630 
4631     def _entropy(self):
4632         return 2-np.log(2)
4633 
4634     @_call_super_mom
4635     @inherit_docstring_from(rv_continuous)
4636     def fit(self, data, *args, **kwds):
4637         if kwds.pop('superfit', False):
4638             return super().fit(data, *args, **kwds)
4639 
4640         data, floc, fscale = _check_fit_input_parameters(self, data,
4641                                                          args, kwds)
4642 
4643         def find_scale(data, loc):
4644             # scale is solution to a fix point problem ([1] 2.6)
4645             # use approximate MLE as starting point ([1] 3.1)
4646             n_observations = data.shape[0]
4647             sorted_data = np.sort(data, axis=0)
4648             p = np.arange(1, n_observations + 1)/(n_observations + 1)
4649             q = 1 - p
4650             pp1 = 1 + p
4651             alpha = p - 0.5 * q * pp1 * np.log(pp1 / q)
4652             beta = 0.5 * q * pp1
4653             sorted_data = sorted_data - loc
4654             B = 2 * np.sum(alpha[1:] * sorted_data[1:])
4655             C = 2 * np.sum(beta[1:] * sorted_data[1:]**2)
4656             # starting guess
4657             scale = ((B + np.sqrt(B**2 + 8 * n_observations * C))
4658                     /(4 * n_observations))
4659 
4660             # relative tolerance of fix point iterator
4661             rtol = 1e-8
4662             relative_residual = 1
4663             shifted_mean = sorted_data.mean()  # y_mean - y_min
4664 
4665             # find fix point by repeated application of eq. (2.6)
4666             # simplify as
4667             # exp(-x) / (1 + exp(-x)) = 1 / (1 + exp(x))
4668             #                         = expit(-x))
4669             while relative_residual > rtol:
4670                 sum_term = sorted_data * sc.expit(-sorted_data/scale)
4671                 scale_new = shifted_mean - 2/n_observations * sum_term.sum()
4672                 relative_residual = abs((scale - scale_new)/scale)
4673                 scale = scale_new
4674             return scale
4675 
4676         # location is independent from the scale
4677         data_min = np.min(data)
4678         if floc is not None:
4679             if data_min < floc:
4680                 # There are values that are less than the specified loc.
4681                 raise FitDataError("halflogistic", lower=floc, upper=np.inf)
4682             loc = floc
4683         else:
4684             # if not provided, location MLE is the minimal data point
4685             loc = data_min
4686 
4687         # scale depends on location
4688         scale = fscale if fscale is not None else find_scale(data, loc)
4689 
4690         return loc, scale
4691 
4692 
4693 halflogistic = halflogistic_gen(a=0.0, name='halflogistic')
4694 
4695 
4696 class halfnorm_gen(rv_continuous):
4697     r"""A half-normal continuous random variable. 
4698  
4699     %(before_notes)s 
4700  
4701     Notes 
4702     ----- 
4703     The probability density function for `halfnorm` is: 
4704  
4705     .. math:: 
4706  
4707         f(x) = \sqrt{2/\pi} \exp(-x^2 / 2) 
4708  
4709     for :math:`x >= 0`. 
4710  
4711     `halfnorm` is a special case of `chi` with ``df=1``. 
4712  
4713     %(after_notes)s 
4714  
4715     %(example)s 
4716  
4717     """
4718     def _shape_info(self):
4719         return []
4720 
4721     def _rvs(self, size=None, random_state=None):
4722         return abs(random_state.standard_normal(size=size))
4723 
4724     def _pdf(self, x):
4725         # halfnorm.pdf(x) = sqrt(2/pi) * exp(-x**2/2)
4726         return np.sqrt(2.0/np.pi)*np.exp(-x*x/2.0)
4727 
4728     def _logpdf(self, x):
4729         return 0.5 * np.log(2.0/np.pi) - x*x/2.0
4730 
4731     def _cdf(self, x):
4732         return sc.erf(x / np.sqrt(2))
4733 
4734     def _ppf(self, q):
4735         return _norm_ppf((1+q)/2.0)
4736 
4737     def _sf(self, x):
4738         return 2 * _norm_sf(x)
4739 
4740     def _isf(self, p):
4741         return _norm_isf(p/2)
4742 
4743     def _stats(self):
4744         return (np.sqrt(2.0/np.pi),
4745                 1-2.0/np.pi,
4746                 np.sqrt(2)*(4-np.pi)/(np.pi-2)**1.5,
4747                 8*(np.pi-3)/(np.pi-2)**2)
4748 
4749     def _entropy(self):
4750         return 0.5*np.log(np.pi/2.0)+0.5
4751 
4752     @_call_super_mom
4753     @inherit_docstring_from(rv_continuous)
4754     def fit(self, data, *args, **kwds):
4755         if kwds.pop('superfit', False):
4756             return super().fit(data, *args, **kwds)
4757 
4758         data, floc, fscale = _check_fit_input_parameters(self, data,
4759                                                          args, kwds)
4760 
4761         data_min = np.min(data)
4762 
4763         if floc is not None:
4764             if data_min < floc:
4765                 # There are values that are less than the specified loc.
4766                 raise FitDataError("halfnorm", lower=floc, upper=np.inf)
4767             loc = floc
4768         else:
4769             loc = data_min
4770 
4771         if fscale is not None:
4772             scale = fscale
4773         else:
4774             scale = stats.moment(data, order=2, center=loc)**0.5
4775 
4776         return loc, scale
4777 
4778 
4779 halfnorm = halfnorm_gen(a=0.0, name='halfnorm')
4780 
4781 
4782 class hypsecant_gen(rv_continuous):
4783     r"""A hyperbolic secant continuous random variable. 
4784  
4785     %(before_notes)s 
4786  
4787     Notes 
4788     ----- 
4789     The probability density function for `hypsecant` is: 
4790  
4791     .. math:: 
4792  
4793         f(x) = \frac{1}{\pi} \text{sech}(x) 
4794  
4795     for a real number :math:`x`. 
4796  
4797     %(after_notes)s 
4798  
4799     %(example)s 
4800  
4801     """
4802     def _shape_info(self):
4803         return []
4804 
4805     def _pdf(self, x):
4806         # hypsecant.pdf(x) = 1/pi * sech(x)
4807         return 1.0/(np.pi*np.cosh(x))
4808 
4809     def _cdf(self, x):
4810         return 2.0/np.pi*np.arctan(np.exp(x))
4811 
4812     def _ppf(self, q):
4813         return np.log(np.tan(np.pi*q/2.0))
4814 
4815     def _sf(self, x):
4816         return 2.0/np.pi*np.arctan(np.exp(-x))
4817 
4818     def _isf(self, q):
4819         return -np.log(np.tan(np.pi*q/2.0))
4820 
4821     def _stats(self):
4822         return 0, np.pi*np.pi/4, 0, 2
4823 
4824     def _entropy(self):
4825         return np.log(2*np.pi)
4826 
4827 
4828 hypsecant = hypsecant_gen(name='hypsecant')
4829 
4830 
4831 class gausshyper_gen(rv_continuous):
4832     r"""A Gauss hypergeometric continuous random variable. 
4833  
4834     %(before_notes)s 
4835  
4836     Notes 
4837     ----- 
4838     The probability density function for `gausshyper` is: 
4839  
4840     .. math:: 
4841  
4842         f(x, a, b, c, z) = C x^{a-1} (1-x)^{b-1} (1+zx)^{-c} 
4843  
4844     for :math:`0 \le x \le 1`, :math:`a,b > 0`, :math:`c` a real number, 
4845     :math:`z > -1`, and :math:`C = \frac{1}{B(a, b) F[2, 1](c, a; a+b; -z)}`. 
4846     :math:`F[2, 1]` is the Gauss hypergeometric function 
4847     `scipy.special.hyp2f1`. 
4848  
4849     `gausshyper` takes :math:`a`, :math:`b`, :math:`c` and :math:`z` as shape 
4850     parameters. 
4851  
4852     %(after_notes)s 
4853  
4854     References 
4855     ---------- 
4856     .. [1] Armero, C., and M. J. Bayarri. "Prior Assessments for Prediction in 
4857            Queues." *Journal of the Royal Statistical Society*. Series D (The 
4858            Statistician) 43, no. 1 (1994): 139-53. doi:10.2307/2348939 
4859  
4860     %(example)s 
4861  
4862     """
4863 
4864     def _argcheck(self, a, b, c, z):
4865         # z > -1 per gh-10134
4866         return (a > 0) & (b > 0) & (c == c) & (z > -1)
4867 
4868     def _shape_info(self):
4869         ia = _ShapeInfo("a", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))
4870         ib = _ShapeInfo("b", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))
4871         ic = _ShapeInfo("c", False, (-np.inf, np.inf), (False, False))
4872         iz = _ShapeInfo("z", False, (-1, np.inf), (False, False))
4873         return [ia, ib, ic, iz]
4874 
4875     def _pdf(self, x, a, b, c, z):
4876         normalization_constant = sc.beta(a, b) * sc.hyp2f1(c, a, a + b, -z)
4877         return (1./normalization_constant * x**(a - 1.) * (1. - x)**(b - 1.0)
4878                 / (1.0 + z*x)**c)
4879 
4880     def _munp(self, n, a, b, c, z):
4881         fac = sc.beta(n+a, b) / sc.beta(a, b)
4882         num = sc.hyp2f1(c, a+n, a+b+n, -z)
4883         den = sc.hyp2f1(c, a, a+b, -z)
4884         return fac*num / den
4885 
4886 
4887 gausshyper = gausshyper_gen(a=0.0, b=1.0, name='gausshyper')
4888 
4889 
4890 class invgamma_gen(rv_continuous):
4891     r"""An inverted gamma continuous random variable. 
4892  
4893     %(before_notes)s 
4894  
4895     Notes 
4896     ----- 
4897     The probability density function for `invgamma` is: 
4898  
4899     .. math:: 
4900  
4901         f(x, a) = \frac{x^{-a-1}}{\Gamma(a)} \exp(-\frac{1}{x}) 
4902  
4903     for :math:`x >= 0`, :math:`a > 0`. :math:`\Gamma` is the gamma function 
4904     (`scipy.special.gamma`). 
4905  
4906     `invgamma` takes ``a`` as a shape parameter for :math:`a`. 
4907  
4908     `invgamma` is a special case of `gengamma` with ``c=-1``, and it is a 
4909     different parameterization of the scaled inverse chi-squared distribution. 
4910     Specifically, if the scaled inverse chi-squared distribution is 
4911     parameterized with degrees of freedom :math:`\nu` and scaling parameter 
4912     :math:`\tau^2`, then it can be modeled using `invgamma` with 
4913     ``a=`` :math:`\nu/2` and ``scale=`` :math:`\nu \tau^2/2`. 
4914  
4915     %(after_notes)s 
4916  
4917     %(example)s 
4918  
4919     """
4920     _support_mask = rv_continuous._open_support_mask
4921 
4922     def _shape_info(self):
4923         return [_ShapeInfo("a", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))]
4924 
4925     def _pdf(self, x, a):
4926         # invgamma.pdf(x, a) = x**(-a-1) / gamma(a) * exp(-1/x)
4927         return np.exp(self._logpdf(x, a))
4928 
4929     def _logpdf(self, x, a):
4930         return -(a+1) * np.log(x) - sc.gammaln(a) - 1.0/x
4931 
4932     def _cdf(self, x, a):
4933         return sc.gammaincc(a, 1.0 / x)
4934 
4935     def _ppf(self, q, a):
4936         return 1.0 / sc.gammainccinv(a, q)
4937 
4938     def _sf(self, x, a):
4939         return sc.gammainc(a, 1.0 / x)
4940 
4941     def _isf(self, q, a):
4942         return 1.0 / sc.gammaincinv(a, q)
4943 
4944     def _stats(self, a, moments='mvsk'):
4945         m1 = _lazywhere(a > 1, (a,), lambda x: 1. / (x - 1.), np.inf)
4946         m2 = _lazywhere(a > 2, (a,), lambda x: 1. / (x - 1.)**2 / (x - 2.),
4947                         np.inf)
4948 
4949         g1, g2 = None, None
4950         if 's' in moments:
4951             g1 = _lazywhere(
4952                 a > 3, (a,),
4953                 lambda x: 4. * np.sqrt(x - 2.) / (x - 3.), np.nan)
4954         if 'k' in moments:
4955             g2 = _lazywhere(
4956                 a > 4, (a,),
4957                 lambda x: 6. * (5. * x - 11.) / (x - 3.) / (x - 4.), np.nan)
4958         return m1, m2, g1, g2
4959 
4960     def _entropy(self, a):
4961         def regular(a):
4962             h = a - (a + 1.0) * sc.psi(a) + sc.gammaln(a)
4963             return h
4964 
4965         def asymptotic(a):
4966             # gammaln(a) ~ a * ln(a) - a - 0.5 * ln(a) + 0.5 * ln(2 * pi)
4967             # psi(a) ~ ln(a) - 1 / (2 * a)
4968             h = ((1 - 3*np.log(a) + np.log(2) + np.log(np.pi))/2
4969                  + 2/3*a**-1. + a**-2./12 - a**-3./90 - a**-4./120)
4970             return h
4971 
4972         h = _lazywhere(a >= 2e2, (a,), f=asymptotic, f2=regular)
4973         return h
4974 
4975 
4976 invgamma = invgamma_gen(a=0.0, name='invgamma')
4977 
4978 
4979 class invgauss_gen(rv_continuous):
4980     r"""An inverse Gaussian continuous random variable. 
4981  
4982     %(before_notes)s 
4983  
4984     Notes 
4985     ----- 
4986     The probability density function for `invgauss` is: 
4987  
4988     .. math:: 
4989  
4990         f(x; \mu) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi x^3}} 
4991                     \exp\left(-\frac{(x-\mu)^2}{2 \mu^2 x}\right) 
4992  
4993     for :math:`x \ge 0` and :math:`\mu > 0`. 
4994  
4995     `invgauss` takes ``mu`` as a shape parameter for :math:`\mu`. 
4996  
4997     %(after_notes)s 
4998  
4999     A common shape-scale parameterization of the inverse Gaussian distribution 
5000     has density 
5001  
5002     .. math:: 
5003  
5004         f(x; \nu, \lambda) = \sqrt{\frac{\lambda}{2 \pi x^3}} 
5005                     \exp\left( -\frac{\lambda(x-\nu)^2}{2 \nu^2 x}\right) 
5006  
5007     Using ``nu`` for :math:`\nu` and ``lam`` for :math:`\lambda`, this 
5008     parameterization is equivalent to the one above with ``mu = nu/lam``, 
5009     ``loc = 0``, and ``scale = lam``. 
5010  
5011     This distribution uses routines from the Boost Math C++ library for 
5012     the computation of the ``ppf`` and ``isf`` methods. [1]_ 
5013  
5014     References 
5015     ---------- 
5016     .. [1] The Boost Developers. "Boost C++ Libraries". https://www.boost.org/. 
5017  
5018     %(example)s 
5019  
5020     """
5021     _support_mask = rv_continuous._open_support_mask
5022 
5023     def _shape_info(self):
5024         return [_ShapeInfo("mu", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))]
5025 
5026     def _rvs(self, mu, size=None, random_state=None):
5027         return random_state.wald(mu, 1.0, size=size)
5028 
5029     def _pdf(self, x, mu):
5030         # invgauss.pdf(x, mu) =
5031         #                  1 / sqrt(2*pi*x**3) * exp(-(x-mu)**2/(2*x*mu**2))
5032         return 1.0/np.sqrt(2*np.pi*x**3.0)*np.exp(-1.0/(2*x)*((x-mu)/mu)**2)
5033 
5034     def _logpdf(self, x, mu):
5035         return -0.5*np.log(2*np.pi) - 1.5*np.log(x) - ((x-mu)/mu)**2/(2*x)
5036 
5037     # approach adapted from equations in
5038     # https://journal.r-project.org/archive/2016-1/giner-smyth.pdf,
5039     # not R code. see gh-13616
5040 
5041     def _logcdf(self, x, mu):
5042         fac = 1 / np.sqrt(x)
5043         a = _norm_logcdf(fac * ((x / mu) - 1))
5044         b = 2 / mu + _norm_logcdf(-fac * ((x / mu) + 1))
5045         return a + np.log1p(np.exp(b - a))
5046 
5047     def _logsf(self, x, mu):
5048         fac = 1 / np.sqrt(x)
5049         a = _norm_logsf(fac * ((x / mu) - 1))
5050         b = 2 / mu + _norm_logcdf(-fac * (x + mu) / mu)
5051         return a + np.log1p(-np.exp(b - a))
5052 
5053     def _sf(self, x, mu):
5054         return np.exp(self._logsf(x, mu))
5055 
5056     def _cdf(self, x, mu):
5057         return np.exp(self._logcdf(x, mu))
5058 
5059     def _ppf(self, x, mu):
5060         with np.errstate(divide='ignore', over='ignore', invalid='ignore'):
5061             x, mu = np.broadcast_arrays(x, mu)
5062             ppf = np.asarray(scu._invgauss_ppf(x, mu, 1))
5063             i_wt = x > 0.5  # "wrong tail" - sometimes too inaccurate
5064             ppf[i_wt] = scu._invgauss_isf(1-x[i_wt], mu[i_wt], 1)
5065             i_nan = np.isnan(ppf)
5066             ppf[i_nan] = super()._ppf(x[i_nan], mu[i_nan])
5067         return ppf
5068 
5069     def _isf(self, x, mu):
5070         with np.errstate(divide='ignore', over='ignore', invalid='ignore'):
5071             x, mu = np.broadcast_arrays(x, mu)
5072             isf = scu._invgauss_isf(x, mu, 1)
5073             i_wt = x > 0.5  # "wrong tail" - sometimes too inaccurate
5074             isf[i_wt] = scu._invgauss_ppf(1-x[i_wt], mu[i_wt], 1)
5075             i_nan = np.isnan(isf)
5076             isf[i_nan] = super()._isf(x[i_nan], mu[i_nan])
5077         return isf
5078 
5079     def _stats(self, mu):
5080         return mu, mu**3.0, 3*np.sqrt(mu), 15*mu
5081 
5082     @inherit_docstring_from(rv_continuous)
5083     def fit(self, data, *args, **kwds):
5084         method = kwds.get('method', 'mle')
5085 
5086         if (isinstance(data, CensoredData) or isinstance(self, wald_gen)
5087                 or method.lower() == 'mm'):
5088             return super().fit(data, *args, **kwds)
5089 
5090         data, fshape_s, floc, fscale = _check_fit_input_parameters(self, data,
5091                                                                    args, kwds)
5092         ''' 
5093         Source: Statistical Distributions, 3rd Edition. Evans, Hastings, 
5094         and Peacock (2000), Page 121. Their shape parameter is equivalent to 
5095         SciPy's with the conversion `fshape_s = fshape / scale`. 
5096  
5097         MLE formulas are not used in 3 conditions: 
5098         - `loc` is not fixed 
5099         - `mu` is fixed 
5100         These cases fall back on the superclass fit method. 
5101         - `loc` is fixed but translation results in negative data raises 
5102           a `FitDataError`. 
5103         '''
5104         if floc is None or fshape_s is not None:
5105             return super().fit(data, *args, **kwds)
5106         elif np.any(data - floc < 0):
5107             raise FitDataError("invgauss", lower=0, upper=np.inf)
5108         else:
5109             data = data - floc
5110             fshape_n = np.mean(data)
5111             if fscale is None:
5112                 fscale = len(data) / (np.sum(data ** -1 - fshape_n ** -1))
5113             fshape_s = fshape_n / fscale
5114         return fshape_s, floc, fscale
5115 
5116     def _entropy(self, mu):
5117         """ 
5118         Ref.: https://moser-isi.ethz.ch/docs/papers/smos-2012-10.pdf (eq. 9) 
5119         """
5120         # a = log(2*pi*e*mu**3)
5121         #   = 1 + log(2*pi) + 3 * log(mu)
5122         a = 1. + np.log(2 * np.pi) + 3 * np.log(mu)
5123         # b = exp(2/mu) * exp1(2/mu)
5124         #   = _scaled_exp1(2/mu) / (2/mu)
5125         r = 2/mu
5126         b = sc._ufuncs._scaled_exp1(r)/r
5127         return 0.5 * a - 1.5 * b
5128 
5129 
5130 invgauss = invgauss_gen(a=0.0, name='invgauss')
5131 
5132 
5133 class geninvgauss_gen(rv_continuous):
5134     r"""A Generalized Inverse Gaussian continuous random variable. 
5135  
5136     %(before_notes)s 
5137  
5138     Notes 
5139     ----- 
5140     The probability density function for `geninvgauss` is: 
5141  
5142     .. math:: 
5143  
5144         f(x, p, b) = x^{p-1} \exp(-b (x + 1/x) / 2) / (2 K_p(b)) 
5145  
5146     where ``x > 0``, `p` is a real number and ``b > 0``\([1]_). 
5147     :math:`K_p` is the modified Bessel function of second kind of order `p` 
5148     (`scipy.special.kv`). 
5149  
5150     %(after_notes)s 
5151  
5152     The inverse Gaussian distribution `stats.invgauss(mu)` is a special case of 
5153     `geninvgauss` with ``p = -1/2``, ``b = 1 / mu`` and ``scale = mu``. 
5154  
5155     Generating random variates is challenging for this distribution. The 
5156     implementation is based on [2]_. 
5157  
5158     References 
5159     ---------- 
5160     .. [1] O. Barndorff-Nielsen, P. Blaesild, C. Halgreen, "First hitting time 
5161        models for the generalized inverse gaussian distribution", 
5162        Stochastic Processes and their Applications 7, pp. 49--54, 1978. 
5163  
5164     .. [2] W. Hoermann and J. Leydold, "Generating generalized inverse Gaussian 
5165        random variates", Statistics and Computing, 24(4), p. 547--557, 2014. 
5166  
5167     %(example)s 
5168  
5169     """
5170     def _argcheck(self, p, b):
5171         return (p == p) & (b > 0)
5172 
5173     def _shape_info(self):
5174         ip = _ShapeInfo("p", False, (-np.inf, np.inf), (False, False))
5175         ib = _ShapeInfo("b", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))
5176         return [ip, ib]
5177 
5178     def _logpdf(self, x, p, b):
5179         # kve instead of kv works better for large values of b
5180         # warn if kve produces infinite values and replace by nan
5181         # otherwise c = -inf and the results are often incorrect
5182         def logpdf_single(x, p, b):
5183             return _stats.geninvgauss_logpdf(x, p, b)
5184 
5185         logpdf_single = np.vectorize(logpdf_single, otypes=[np.float64])
5186 
5187         z = logpdf_single(x, p, b)
5188         if np.isnan(z).any():
5189             msg = ("Infinite values encountered in scipy.special.kve(p, b). "
5190                    "Values replaced by NaN to avoid incorrect results.")
5191             warnings.warn(msg, RuntimeWarning, stacklevel=3)
5192         return z
5193 
5194     def _pdf(self, x, p, b):
5195         # relying on logpdf avoids overflow of x**(p-1) for large x and p
5196         return np.exp(self._logpdf(x, p, b))
5197 
5198     def _cdf(self, x, p, b):
5199         _a, _b = self._get_support(p, b)
5200 
5201         def _cdf_single(x, p, b):
5202             user_data = np.array([p, b], float).ctypes.data_as(ctypes.c_void_p)
5203             llc = LowLevelCallable.from_cython(_stats, '_geninvgauss_pdf',
5204                                                user_data)
5205 
5206             return integrate.quad(llc, _a, x)[0]
5207 
5208         _cdf_single = np.vectorize(_cdf_single, otypes=[np.float64])
5209 
5210         return _cdf_single(x, p, b)
5211 
5212     def _logquasipdf(self, x, p, b):
5213         # log of the quasi-density (w/o normalizing constant) used in _rvs
5214         return _lazywhere(x > 0, (x, p, b),
5215                           lambda x, p, b: (p - 1)*np.log(x) - b*(x + 1/x)/2,
5216                           -np.inf)
5217 
5218     def _rvs(self, p, b, size=None, random_state=None):
5219         # if p and b are scalar, use _rvs_scalar, otherwise need to create
5220         # output by iterating over parameters
5221         if np.isscalar(p) and np.isscalar(b):
5222             out = self._rvs_scalar(p, b, size, random_state)
5223         elif p.size == 1 and b.size == 1:
5224             out = self._rvs_scalar(p.item(), b.item(), size, random_state)
5225         else:
5226             # When this method is called, size will be a (possibly empty)
5227             # tuple of integers.  It will not be None; if `size=None` is passed
5228             # to `rvs()`, size will be the empty tuple ().
5229 
5230             p, b = np.broadcast_arrays(p, b)
5231             # p and b now have the same shape.
5232 
5233             # `shp` is the shape of the blocks of random variates that are
5234             # generated for each combination of parameters associated with
5235             # broadcasting p and b.
5236             # bc is a tuple the same length as size.  The values
5237             # in bc are bools.  If bc[j] is True, it means that
5238             # entire axis is filled in for a given combination of the
5239             # broadcast arguments.
5240             shp, bc = _check_shape(p.shape, size)
5241 
5242             # `numsamples` is the total number of variates to be generated
5243             # for each combination of the input arguments.
5244             numsamples = int(np.prod(shp))
5245 
5246             # `out` is the array to be returned.  It is filled in the
5247             # loop below.
5248             out = np.empty(size)
5249 
5250             it = np.nditer([p, b],
5251                            flags=['multi_index'],
5252                            op_flags=[['readonly'], ['readonly']])
5253             while not it.finished:
5254                 # Convert the iterator's multi_index into an index into the
5255                 # `out` array where the call to _rvs_scalar() will be stored.
5256                 # Where bc is True, we use a full slice; otherwise we use the
5257                 # index value from it.multi_index.  len(it.multi_index) might
5258                 # be less than len(bc), and in that case we want to align these
5259                 # two sequences to the right, so the loop variable j runs from
5260                 # -len(size) to 0.  This doesn't cause an IndexError, as
5261                 # bc[j] will be True in those cases where it.multi_index[j]
5262                 # would cause an IndexError.
5263                 idx = tuple((it.multi_index[j] if not bc[j] else slice(None))
5264                             for j in range(-len(size), 0))
5265                 out[idx] = self._rvs_scalar(it[0], it[1], numsamples,
5266                                             random_state).reshape(shp)
5267                 it.iternext()
5268 
5269         if size == ():
5270             out = out.item()
5271         return out
5272 
5273     def _rvs_scalar(self, p, b, numsamples, random_state):
5274         # following [2], the quasi-pdf is used instead of the pdf for the
5275         # generation of rvs
5276         invert_res = False
5277         if not numsamples:
5278             numsamples = 1
5279         if p < 0:
5280             # note: if X is geninvgauss(p, b), then 1/X is geninvgauss(-p, b)
5281             p = -p
5282             invert_res = True
5283         m = self._mode(p, b)
5284 
5285         # determine method to be used following [2]
5286         ratio_unif = True
5287         if p >= 1 or b > 1:
5288             # ratio of uniforms with mode shift below
5289             mode_shift = True
5290         elif b >= min(0.5, 2 * np.sqrt(1 - p) / 3):
5291             # ratio of uniforms without mode shift below
5292             mode_shift = False
5293         else:
5294             # new algorithm in [2]
5295             ratio_unif = False
5296 
5297         # prepare sampling of rvs
5298         size1d = tuple(np.atleast_1d(numsamples))
5299         N = np.prod(size1d)  # number of rvs needed, reshape upon return
5300         x = np.zeros(N)
5301         simulated = 0
5302 
5303         if ratio_unif:
5304             # use ratio of uniforms method
5305             if mode_shift:
5306                 a2 = -2 * (p + 1) / b - m
5307                 a1 = 2 * m * (p - 1) / b - 1
5308                 # find roots of x**3 + a2*x**2 + a1*x + m (Cardano's formula)
5309                 p1 = a1 - a2**2 / 3
5310                 q1 = 2 * a2**3 / 27 - a2 * a1 / 3 + m
5311                 phi = np.arccos(-q1 * np.sqrt(-27 / p1**3) / 2)
5312                 s1 = -np.sqrt(-4 * p1 / 3)
5313                 root1 = s1 * np.cos(phi / 3 + np.pi / 3) - a2 / 3
5314                 root2 = -s1 * np.cos(phi / 3) - a2 / 3
5315                 # root3 = s1 * np.cos(phi / 3 - np.pi / 3) - a2 / 3
5316 
5317                 # if g is the quasipdf, rescale: g(x) / g(m) which we can write
5318                 # as exp(log(g(x)) - log(g(m))). This is important
5319                 # since for large values of p and b, g cannot be evaluated.
5320                 # denote the rescaled quasipdf by h
5321                 lm = self._logquasipdf(m, p, b)
5322                 d1 = self._logquasipdf(root1, p, b) - lm
5323                 d2 = self._logquasipdf(root2, p, b) - lm
5324                 # compute the bounding rectangle w.r.t. h. Note that
5325                 # np.exp(0.5*d1) = np.sqrt(g(root1)/g(m)) = np.sqrt(h(root1))
5326                 vmin = (root1 - m) * np.exp(0.5 * d1)
5327                 vmax = (root2 - m) * np.exp(0.5 * d2)
5328                 umax = 1  # umax = sqrt(h(m)) = 1
5329 
5330                 def logqpdf(x):
5331                     return self._logquasipdf(x, p, b) - lm
5332 
5333                 c = m
5334             else:
5335                 # ratio of uniforms without mode shift
5336                 # compute np.sqrt(quasipdf(m))
5337                 umax = np.exp(0.5*self._logquasipdf(m, p, b))
5338                 xplus = ((1 + p) + np.sqrt((1 + p)**2 + b**2))/b
5339                 vmin = 0
5340                 # compute xplus * np.sqrt(quasipdf(xplus))
5341                 vmax = xplus * np.exp(0.5 * self._logquasipdf(xplus, p, b))
5342                 c = 0
5343 
5344                 def logqpdf(x):
5345                     return self._logquasipdf(x, p, b)
5346 
5347             if vmin >= vmax:
5348                 raise ValueError("vmin must be smaller than vmax.")
5349             if umax <= 0:
5350                 raise ValueError("umax must be positive.")
5351 
5352             i = 1
5353             while simulated < N:
5354                 k = N - simulated
5355                 # simulate uniform rvs on [0, umax] and [vmin, vmax]
5356                 u = umax * random_state.uniform(size=k)
5357                 v = random_state.uniform(size=k)
5358                 v = vmin + (vmax - vmin) * v
5359                 rvs = v / u + c
5360                 # rewrite acceptance condition u**2 <= pdf(rvs) by taking logs
5361                 accept = (2*np.log(u) <= logqpdf(rvs))
5362                 num_accept = np.sum(accept)
5363                 if num_accept > 0:
5364                     x[simulated:(simulated + num_accept)] = rvs[accept]
5365                     simulated += num_accept
5366 
5367                 if (simulated == 0) and (i*N >= 50000):
5368                     msg = ("Not a single random variate could be generated "
5369                            f"in {i*N} attempts. Sampling does not appear to "
5370                            "work for the provided parameters.")
5371                     raise RuntimeError(msg)
5372                 i += 1
5373         else:
5374             # use new algorithm in [2]
5375             x0 = b / (1 - p)
5376             xs = np.max((x0, 2 / b))
5377             k1 = np.exp(self._logquasipdf(m, p, b))
5378             A1 = k1 * x0
5379             if x0 < 2 / b:
5380                 k2 = np.exp(-b)
5381                 if p > 0:
5382                     A2 = k2 * ((2 / b)**p - x0**p) / p
5383                 else:
5384                     A2 = k2 * np.log(2 / b**2)
5385             else:
5386                 k2, A2 = 0, 0
5387             k3 = xs**(p - 1)
5388             A3 = 2 * k3 * np.exp(-xs * b / 2) / b
5389             A = A1 + A2 + A3
5390 
5391             # [2]: rejection constant is < 2.73; so expected runtime is finite
5392             while simulated < N:
5393                 k = N - simulated
5394                 h, rvs = np.zeros(k), np.zeros(k)
5395                 # simulate uniform rvs on [x1, x2] and [0, y2]
5396                 u = random_state.uniform(size=k)
5397                 v = A * random_state.uniform(size=k)
5398                 cond1 = v <= A1
5399                 cond2 = np.logical_not(cond1) & (v <= A1 + A2)
5400                 cond3 = np.logical_not(cond1 | cond2)
5401                 # subdomain (0, x0)
5402                 rvs[cond1] = x0 * v[cond1] / A1
5403                 h[cond1] = k1
5404                 # subdomain (x0, 2 / b)
5405                 if p > 0:
5406                     rvs[cond2] = (x0**p + (v[cond2] - A1) * p / k2)**(1 / p)
5407                 else:
5408                     rvs[cond2] = b * np.exp((v[cond2] - A1) * np.exp(b))
5409                 h[cond2] = k2 * rvs[cond2]**(p - 1)
5410                 # subdomain (xs, infinity)
5411                 z = np.exp(-xs * b / 2) - b * (v[cond3] - A1 - A2) / (2 * k3)
5412                 rvs[cond3] = -2 / b * np.log(z)
5413                 h[cond3] = k3 * np.exp(-rvs[cond3] * b / 2)
5414                 # apply rejection method
5415                 accept = (np.log(u * h) <= self._logquasipdf(rvs, p, b))
5416                 num_accept = sum(accept)
5417                 if num_accept > 0:
5418                     x[simulated:(simulated + num_accept)] = rvs[accept]
5419                     simulated += num_accept
5420 
5421         rvs = np.reshape(x, size1d)
5422         if invert_res:
5423             rvs = 1 / rvs
5424         return rvs
5425 
5426     def _mode(self, p, b):
5427         # distinguish cases to avoid catastrophic cancellation (see [2])
5428         if p < 1:
5429             return b / (np.sqrt((p - 1)**2 + b**2) + 1 - p)
5430         else:
5431             return (np.sqrt((1 - p)**2 + b**2) - (1 - p)) / b
5432 
5433     def _munp(self, n, p, b):
5434         num = sc.kve(p + n, b)
5435         denom = sc.kve(p, b)
5436         inf_vals = np.isinf(num) | np.isinf(denom)
5437         if inf_vals.any():
5438             msg = ("Infinite values encountered in the moment calculation "
5439                    "involving scipy.special.kve. Values replaced by NaN to "
5440                    "avoid incorrect results.")
5441             warnings.warn(msg, RuntimeWarning, stacklevel=3)
5442             m = np.full_like(num, np.nan, dtype=np.float64)
5443             m[~inf_vals] = num[~inf_vals] / denom[~inf_vals]
5444         else:
5445             m = num / denom
5446         return m
5447 
5448 
5449 geninvgauss = geninvgauss_gen(a=0.0, name="geninvgauss")
5450 
5451 
5452 class norminvgauss_gen(rv_continuous):
5453     r"""A Normal Inverse Gaussian continuous random variable. 
5454  
5455     %(before_notes)s 
5456  
5457     Notes 
5458     ----- 
5459     The probability density function for `norminvgauss` is: 
5460  
5461     .. math:: 
5462  
5463         f(x, a, b) = \frac{a \, K_1(a \sqrt{1 + x^2})}{\pi \sqrt{1 + x^2}} \, 
5464                      \exp(\sqrt{a^2 - b^2} + b x) 
5465  
5466     where :math:`x` is a real number, the parameter :math:`a` is the tail 
5467     heaviness and :math:`b` is the asymmetry parameter satisfying 
5468     :math:`a > 0` and :math:`|b| <= a`. 
5469     :math:`K_1` is the modified Bessel function of second kind 
5470     (`scipy.special.k1`). 
5471  
5472     %(after_notes)s 
5473  
5474     A normal inverse Gaussian random variable `Y` with parameters `a` and `b` 
5475     can be expressed as a normal mean-variance mixture: 
5476     ``Y = b * V + sqrt(V) * X`` where `X` is ``norm(0,1)`` and `V` is 
5477     ``invgauss(mu=1/sqrt(a**2 - b**2))``. This representation is used 
5478     to generate random variates. 
5479  
5480     Another common parametrization of the distribution (see Equation 2.1 in 
5481     [2]_) is given by the following expression of the pdf: 
5482  
5483     .. math:: 
5484  
5485         g(x, \alpha, \beta, \delta, \mu) = 
5486         \frac{\alpha\delta K_1\left(\alpha\sqrt{\delta^2 + (x - \mu)^2}\right)} 
5487         {\pi \sqrt{\delta^2 + (x - \mu)^2}} \, 
5488         e^{\delta \sqrt{\alpha^2 - \beta^2} + \beta (x - \mu)} 
5489  
5490     In SciPy, this corresponds to 
5491     `a = alpha * delta, b = beta * delta, loc = mu, scale=delta`. 
5492  
5493     References 
5494     ---------- 
5495     .. [1] O. Barndorff-Nielsen, "Hyperbolic Distributions and Distributions on 
5496            Hyperbolae", Scandinavian Journal of Statistics, Vol. 5(3), 
5497            pp. 151-157, 1978. 
5498  
5499     .. [2] O. Barndorff-Nielsen, "Normal Inverse Gaussian Distributions and 
5500            Stochastic Volatility Modelling", Scandinavian Journal of 
5501            Statistics, Vol. 24, pp. 1-13, 1997. 
5502  
5503     %(example)s 
5504  
5505     """
5506     _support_mask = rv_continuous._open_support_mask
5507 
5508     def _argcheck(self, a, b):
5509         return (a > 0) & (np.absolute(b) < a)
5510 
5511     def _shape_info(self):
5512         ia = _ShapeInfo("a", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))
5513         ib = _ShapeInfo("b", False, (-np.inf, np.inf), (False, False))
5514         return [ia, ib]
5515 
5516     def _fitstart(self, data):
5517         # Arbitrary, but the default a = b = 1 is not valid; the distribution
5518         # requires |b| < a.
5519         return super()._fitstart(data, args=(1, 0.5))
5520 
5521     def _pdf(self, x, a, b):
5522         gamma = np.sqrt(a**2 - b**2)
5523         fac1 = a / np.pi
5524         sq = np.hypot(1, x)  # reduce overflows
5525         return fac1 * sc.k1e(a * sq) * np.exp(b*x - a*sq + gamma) / sq
5526 
5527     def _sf(self, x, a, b):
5528         if np.isscalar(x):
5529             # If x is a scalar, then so are a and b.
5530             return integrate.quad(self._pdf, x, np.inf, args=(a, b))[0]
5531         else:
5532             a = np.atleast_1d(a)
5533             b = np.atleast_1d(b)
5534             result = []
5535             for (x0, a0, b0) in zip(x, a, b):
5536                 result.append(integrate.quad(self._pdf, x0, np.inf,
5537                                              args=(a0, b0))[0])
5538             return np.array(result)
5539 
5540     def _isf(self, q, a, b):
5541         def _isf_scalar(q, a, b):
5542 
5543             def eq(x, a, b, q):
5544                 # Solve eq(x, a, b, q) = 0 to obtain isf(x, a, b) = q.
5545                 return self._sf(x, a, b) - q
5546 
5547             # Find a bracketing interval for the root.
5548             # Start at the mean, and grow the length of the interval
5549             # by 2 each iteration until there is a sign change in eq.
5550             xm = self.mean(a, b)
5551             em = eq(xm, a, b, q)
5552             if em == 0:
5553                 # Unlikely, but might as well check.
5554                 return xm
5555             if em > 0:
5556                 delta = 1
5557                 left = xm
5558                 right = xm + delta
5559                 while eq(right, a, b, q) > 0:
5560                     delta = 2*delta
5561                     right = xm + delta
5562             else:
5563                 # em < 0
5564                 delta = 1
5565                 right = xm
5566                 left = xm - delta
5567                 while eq(left, a, b, q) < 0:
5568                     delta = 2*delta
5569                     left = xm - delta
5570             result = optimize.brentq(eq, left, right, args=(a, b, q),
5571                                      xtol=self.xtol)
5572             return result
5573 
5574         if np.isscalar(q):
5575             return _isf_scalar(q, a, b)
5576         else:
5577             result = []
5578             for (q0, a0, b0) in zip(q, a, b):
5579                 result.append(_isf_scalar(q0, a0, b0))
5580             return np.array(result)
5581 
5582     def _rvs(self, a, b, size=None, random_state=None):
5583         # note: X = b * V + sqrt(V) * X is norminvgaus(a,b) if X is standard
5584         # normal and V is invgauss(mu=1/sqrt(a**2 - b**2))
5585         gamma = np.sqrt(a**2 - b**2)
5586         ig = invgauss.rvs(mu=1/gamma, size=size, random_state=random_state)
5587         return b * ig + np.sqrt(ig) * norm.rvs(size=size,
5588                                                random_state=random_state)
5589 
5590     def _stats(self, a, b):
5591         gamma = np.sqrt(a**2 - b**2)
5592         mean = b / gamma
5593         variance = a**2 / gamma**3
5594         skewness = 3.0 * b / (a * np.sqrt(gamma))
5595         kurtosis = 3.0 * (1 + 4 * b**2 / a**2) / gamma
5596         return mean, variance, skewness, kurtosis
5597 
5598 
5599 norminvgauss = norminvgauss_gen(name="norminvgauss")
5600 
5601 
5602 class invweibull_gen(rv_continuous):
5603     """An inverted Weibull continuous random variable. 
5604  
5605     This distribution is also known as the Frchet distribution or the 
5606     type II extreme value distribution. 
5607  
5608     %(before_notes)s 
5609  
5610     Notes 
5611     ----- 
5612     The probability density function for `invweibull` is: 
5613  
5614     .. math:: 
5615  
5616         f(x, c) = c x^{-c-1} \\exp(-x^{-c}) 
5617  
5618     for :math:`x > 0`, :math:`c > 0`. 
5619  
5620     `invweibull` takes ``c`` as a shape parameter for :math:`c`. 
5621  
5622     %(after_notes)s 
5623  
5624     References 
5625     ---------- 
5626     F.R.S. de Gusmao, E.M.M Ortega and G.M. Cordeiro, "The generalized inverse 
5627     Weibull distribution", Stat. Papers, vol. 52, pp. 591-619, 2011. 
5628  
5629     %(example)s 
5630  
5631     """
5632     _support_mask = rv_continuous._open_support_mask
5633 
5634     def _shape_info(self):
5635         return [_ShapeInfo("c", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))]
5636 
5637     def _pdf(self, x, c):
5638         # invweibull.pdf(x, c) = c * x**(-c-1) * exp(-x**(-c))
5639         xc1 = np.power(x, -c - 1.0)
5640         xc2 = np.power(x, -c)
5641         xc2 = np.exp(-xc2)
5642         return c * xc1 * xc2
5643 
5644     def _cdf(self, x, c):
5645         xc1 = np.power(x, -c)
5646         return np.exp(-xc1)
5647 
5648     def _sf(self, x, c):
5649         return -np.expm1(-x**-c)
5650 
5651     def _ppf(self, q, c):
5652         return np.power(-np.log(q), -1.0/c)
5653 
5654     def _isf(self, p, c):
5655         return (-np.log1p(-p))**(-1/c)
5656 
5657     def _munp(self, n, c):
5658         return sc.gamma(1 - n / c)
5659 
5660     def _entropy(self, c):
5661         return 1+_EULER + _EULER / c - np.log(c)
5662 
5663     def _fitstart(self, data, args=None):
5664         # invweibull requires c > 1 for the first moment to exist, so use 2.0
5665         args = (2.0,) if args is None else args
5666         return super()._fitstart(data, args=args)
5667 
5668 
5669 invweibull = invweibull_gen(a=0, name='invweibull')
5670 
5671 
5672 class jf_skew_t_gen(rv_continuous):
5673     r"""Jones and Faddy skew-t distribution. 
5674  
5675     %(before_notes)s 
5676  
5677     Notes 
5678     ----- 
5679     The probability density function for `jf_skew_t` is: 
5680  
5681     .. math:: 
5682  
5683         f(x; a, b) = C_{a,b}^{-1} 
5684                     \left(1+\frac{x}{\left(a+b+x^2\right)^{1/2}}\right)^{a+1/2} 
5685                     \left(1-\frac{x}{\left(a+b+x^2\right)^{1/2}}\right)^{b+1/2} 
5686  
5687     for real numbers :math:`a>0` and :math:`b>0`, where 
5688     :math:`C_{a,b} = 2^{a+b-1}B(a,b)(a+b)^{1/2}`, and :math:`B` denotes the 
5689     beta function (`scipy.special.beta`). 
5690  
5691     When :math:`a<b`, the distribution is negatively skewed, and when 
5692     :math:`a>b`, the distribution is positively skewed. If :math:`a=b`, then 
5693     we recover the `t` distribution with :math:`2a` degrees of freedom. 
5694  
5695     `jf_skew_t` takes :math:`a` and :math:`b` as shape parameters. 
5696  
5697     %(after_notes)s 
5698  
5699     References 
5700     ---------- 
5701     .. [1] M.C. Jones and M.J. Faddy. "A skew extension of the t distribution, 
5702            with applications" *Journal of the Royal Statistical Society*. 
5703            Series B (Statistical Methodology) 65, no. 1 (2003): 159-174. 
5704            :doi:`10.1111/1467-9868.00378` 
5705  
5706     %(example)s 
5707  
5708     """
5709     def _shape_info(self):
5710         ia = _ShapeInfo("a", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))
5711         ib = _ShapeInfo("b", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))
5712         return [ia, ib]
5713 
5714     def _pdf(self, x, a, b):
5715         c = 2 ** (a + b - 1) * sc.beta(a, b) * np.sqrt(a + b)
5716         d1 = (1 + x / np.sqrt(a + b + x ** 2)) ** (a + 0.5)
5717         d2 = (1 - x / np.sqrt(a + b + x ** 2)) ** (b + 0.5)
5718         return d1 * d2 / c
5719 
5720     def _rvs(self, a, b, size=None, random_state=None):
5721         d1 = random_state.beta(a, b, size)
5722         d2 = (2 * d1 - 1) * np.sqrt(a + b)
5723         d3 = 2 * np.sqrt(d1 * (1 - d1))
5724         return d2 / d3
5725 
5726     def _cdf(self, x, a, b):
5727         y = (1 + x / np.sqrt(a + b + x ** 2)) * 0.5
5728         return sc.betainc(a, b, y)
5729 
5730     def _sf(self, x, a, b):
5731         y = (1 + x / np.sqrt(a + b + x ** 2)) * 0.5
5732         return sc.betaincc(a, b, y)
5733 
5734     def _ppf(self, q, a, b):
5735         d1 = beta.ppf(q, a, b)
5736         d2 = (2 * d1 - 1) * np.sqrt(a + b)
5737         d3 = 2 * np.sqrt(d1 * (1 - d1))
5738         return d2 / d3
5739 
5740     def _munp(self, n, a, b):
5741         """Returns the n-th moment(s) where all the following hold: 
5742  
5743         - n >= 0 
5744         - a > n / 2 
5745         - b > n / 2 
5746  
5747         The result is np.nan in all other cases. 
5748         """
5749         def nth_moment(n_k, a_k, b_k):
5750             """Computes E[T^(n_k)] where T is skew-t distributed with 
5751             parameters a_k and b_k. 
5752             """
5753             num = (a_k + b_k) ** (0.5 * n_k)
5754             denom = 2 ** n_k * sc.beta(a_k, b_k)
5755 
5756             indices = np.arange(n_k + 1)
5757             sgn = np.where(indices % 2 > 0, -1, 1)
5758             d = sc.beta(a_k + 0.5 * n_k - indices, b_k - 0.5 * n_k + indices)
5759             sum_terms = sc.comb(n_k, indices) * sgn * d
5760 
5761             return num / denom * sum_terms.sum()
5762 
5763         nth_moment_valid = (a > 0.5 * n) & (b > 0.5 * n) & (n >= 0)
5764         return _lazywhere(
5765             nth_moment_valid,
5766             (n, a, b),
5767             np.vectorize(nth_moment, otypes=[np.float64]),
5768             np.nan,
5769         )
5770 
5771 
5772 jf_skew_t = jf_skew_t_gen(name='jf_skew_t')
5773 
5774 
5775 class johnsonsb_gen(rv_continuous):
5776     r"""A Johnson SB continuous random variable. 
5777  
5778     %(before_notes)s 
5779  
5780     See Also 
5781     -------- 
5782     johnsonsu 
5783  
5784     Notes 
5785     ----- 
5786     The probability density function for `johnsonsb` is: 
5787  
5788     .. math:: 
5789  
5790         f(x, a, b) = \frac{b}{x(1-x)}  \phi(a + b \log \frac{x}{1-x} ) 
5791  
5792     where :math:`x`, :math:`a`, and :math:`b` are real scalars; :math:`b > 0` 
5793     and :math:`x \in [0,1]`.  :math:`\phi` is the pdf of the normal 
5794     distribution. 
5795  
5796     `johnsonsb` takes :math:`a` and :math:`b` as shape parameters. 
5797  
5798     %(after_notes)s 
5799  
5800     %(example)s 
5801  
5802     """
5803     _support_mask = rv_continuous._open_support_mask
5804 
5805     def _argcheck(self, a, b):
5806         return (b > 0) & (a == a)
5807 
5808     def _shape_info(self):
5809         ia = _ShapeInfo("a", False, (-np.inf, np.inf), (False, False))
5810         ib = _ShapeInfo("b", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))
5811         return [ia, ib]
5812 
5813     def _pdf(self, x, a, b):
5814         # johnsonsb.pdf(x, a, b) = b / (x*(1-x)) * phi(a + b * log(x/(1-x)))
5815         trm = _norm_pdf(a + b*sc.logit(x))
5816         return b*1.0/(x*(1-x))*trm
5817 
5818     def _cdf(self, x, a, b):
5819         return _norm_cdf(a + b*sc.logit(x))
5820 
5821     def _ppf(self, q, a, b):
5822         return sc.expit(1.0 / b * (_norm_ppf(q) - a))
5823 
5824     def _sf(self, x, a, b):
5825         return _norm_sf(a + b*sc.logit(x))
5826 
5827     def _isf(self, q, a, b):
5828         return sc.expit(1.0 / b * (_norm_isf(q) - a))
5829 
5830 
5831 johnsonsb = johnsonsb_gen(a=0.0, b=1.0, name='johnsonsb')
5832 
5833 
5834 class johnsonsu_gen(rv_continuous):
5835     r"""A Johnson SU continuous random variable. 
5836  
5837     %(before_notes)s 
5838  
5839     See Also 
5840     -------- 
5841     johnsonsb 
5842  
5843     Notes 
5844     ----- 
5845     The probability density function for `johnsonsu` is: 
5846  
5847     .. math:: 
5848  
5849         f(x, a, b) = \frac{b}{\sqrt{x^2 + 1}} 
5850                      \phi(a + b \log(x + \sqrt{x^2 + 1})) 
5851  
5852     where :math:`x`, :math:`a`, and :math:`b` are real scalars; :math:`b > 0`. 
5853     :math:`\phi` is the pdf of the normal distribution. 
5854  
5855     `johnsonsu` takes :math:`a` and :math:`b` as shape parameters. 
5856  
5857     The first four central moments are calculated according to the formulas 
5858     in [1]_. 
5859  
5860     %(after_notes)s 
5861  
5862     References 
5863     ---------- 
5864     .. [1] Taylor Enterprises. "Johnson Family of Distributions". 
5865        https://variation.com/wp-content/distribution_analyzer_help/hs126.htm 
5866  
5867     %(example)s 
5868  
5869     """
5870     def _argcheck(self, a, b):
5871         return (b > 0) & (a == a)
5872 
5873     def _shape_info(self):
5874         ia = _ShapeInfo("a", False, (-np.inf, np.inf), (False, False))
5875         ib = _ShapeInfo("b", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))
5876         return [ia, ib]
5877 
5878     def _pdf(self, x, a, b):
5879         # johnsonsu.pdf(x, a, b) = b / sqrt(x**2 + 1) *
5880         #                          phi(a + b * log(x + sqrt(x**2 + 1)))
5881         x2 = x*x
5882         trm = _norm_pdf(a + b * np.arcsinh(x))
5883         return b*1.0/np.sqrt(x2+1.0)*trm
5884 
5885     def _cdf(self, x, a, b):
5886         return _norm_cdf(a + b * np.arcsinh(x))
5887 
5888     def _ppf(self, q, a, b):
5889         return np.sinh((_norm_ppf(q) - a) / b)
5890 
5891     def _sf(self, x, a, b):
5892         return _norm_sf(a + b * np.arcsinh(x))
5893 
5894     def _isf(self, x, a, b):
5895         return np.sinh((_norm_isf(x) - a) / b)
5896 
5897     def _stats(self, a, b, moments='mv'):
5898         # Naive implementation of first and second moment to address gh-18071.
5899         # https://variation.com/wp-content/distribution_analyzer_help/hs126.htm
5900         # Numerical improvements left to future enhancements.
5901         mu, mu2, g1, g2 = None, None, None, None
5902 
5903         bn2 = b**-2.
5904         expbn2 = np.exp(bn2)
5905         a_b = a / b
5906 
5907         if 'm' in moments:
5908             mu = -expbn2**0.5 * np.sinh(a_b)
5909         if 'v' in moments:
5910             mu2 = 0.5*sc.expm1(bn2)*(expbn2*np.cosh(2*a_b) + 1)
5911         if 's' in moments:
5912             t1 = expbn2**.5 * sc.expm1(bn2)**0.5
5913             t2 = 3*np.sinh(a_b)
5914             t3 = expbn2 * (expbn2 + 2) * np.sinh(3*a_b)
5915             denom = np.sqrt(2) * (1 + expbn2 * np.cosh(2*a_b))**(3/2)
5916             g1 = -t1 * (t2 + t3) / denom
5917         if 'k' in moments:
5918             t1 = 3 + 6*expbn2
5919             t2 = 4*expbn2**2 * (expbn2 + 2) * np.cosh(2*a_b)
5920             t3 = expbn2**2 * np.cosh(4*a_b)
5921             t4 = -3 + 3*expbn2**2 + 2*expbn2**3 + expbn2**4
5922             denom = 2*(1 + expbn2*np.cosh(2*a_b))**2
5923             g2 = (t1 + t2 + t3*t4) / denom - 3
5924         return mu, mu2, g1, g2
5925 
5926 
5927 johnsonsu = johnsonsu_gen(name='johnsonsu')
5928 
5929 
5930 class landau_gen(rv_continuous):
5931     r"""A Landau continuous random variable. 
5932  
5933     %(before_notes)s 
5934  
5935     Notes 
5936     ----- 
5937     The probability density function for `landau` ([1]_, [2]_) is: 
5938  
5939     .. math:: 
5940  
5941         f(x) = \frac{1}{\pi}\int_0^\infty \exp(-t \log t - xt)\sin(\pi t) dt 
5942  
5943     for a real number :math:`x`. 
5944  
5945     %(after_notes)s 
5946  
5947     Often (e.g. [2]_), the Landau distribution is parameterized in terms of a 
5948     location parameter :math:`\mu` and scale parameter :math:`c`, the latter of 
5949     which *also* introduces a location shift. If ``mu`` and ``c`` are used to 
5950     represent these parameters, this corresponds with SciPy's parameterization 
5951     with ``loc = mu + 2*c / np.pi * np.log(c)`` and ``scale = c``. 
5952  
5953     This distribution uses routines from the Boost Math C++ library for 
5954     the computation of the ``pdf``, ``cdf``, ``ppf``, ``sf`` and ``isf`` 
5955     methods. [1]_ 
5956  
5957     References 
5958     ---------- 
5959     .. [1] Landau, L. (1944). "On the energy loss of fast particles by 
5960            ionization". J. Phys. (USSR). 8: 201. 
5961     .. [2] "Landau Distribution", Wikipedia, 
5962            https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Landau_distribution 
5963     .. [3] Chambers, J. M., Mallows, C. L., & Stuck, B. (1976). 
5964            "A method for simulating stable random variables." 
5965            Journal of the American Statistical Association, 71(354), 340-344. 
5966     .. [4] The Boost Developers. "Boost C++ Libraries". https://www.boost.org/. 
5967     .. [5] Yoshimura, T. "Numerical Evaluation and High Precision Approximation 
5968            Formula for Landau Distribution". 
5969            :doi:`10.36227/techrxiv.171822215.53612870/v2` 
5970  
5971     %(example)s 
5972  
5973     """
5974     def _shape_info(self):
5975         return []
5976 
5977     def _entropy(self):
5978         # Computed with mpmath - see gh-19145
5979         return 2.37263644000448182
5980 
5981     def _pdf(self, x):
5982         return scu._landau_pdf(x, 0, 1)
5983 
5984     def _cdf(self, x):
5985         return scu._landau_cdf(x, 0, 1)
5986 
5987     def _sf(self, x):
5988         return scu._landau_sf(x, 0, 1)
5989 
5990     def _ppf(self, p):
5991         return scu._landau_ppf(p, 0, 1)
5992 
5993     def _isf(self, p):
5994         return scu._landau_isf(p, 0, 1)
5995 
5996     def _stats(self):
5997         return np.nan, np.nan, np.nan, np.nan
5998 
5999     def _munp(self, n):
6000         return np.nan if n > 0 else 1
6001 
6002     def _fitstart(self, data, args=None):
6003         # Initialize ML guesses using quartiles instead of moments.
6004         if isinstance(data, CensoredData):
6005             data = data._uncensor()
6006         p25, p50, p75 = np.percentile(data, [25, 50, 75])
6007         return p50, (p75 - p25)/2
6008 
6009     def _rvs(self, size=None, random_state=None):
6010         # Method from https://www.jstor.org/stable/2285309 Eq. 2.4
6011         pi_2 = np.pi / 2
6012         U = random_state.uniform(-np.pi / 2, np.pi / 2, size=size)
6013         W = random_state.standard_exponential(size=size)
6014         S = 2 / np.pi * ((pi_2 + U) * np.tan(U)
6015                          - np.log((pi_2 * W * np.cos(U)) / (pi_2 + U)))
6016         return S
6017 
6018 
6019 landau = landau_gen(name='landau')
6020 
6021 
6022 class laplace_gen(rv_continuous):
6023     r"""A Laplace continuous random variable. 
6024  
6025     %(before_notes)s 
6026  
6027     Notes 
6028     ----- 
6029     The probability density function for `laplace` is 
6030  
6031     .. math:: 
6032  
6033         f(x) = \frac{1}{2} \exp(-|x|) 
6034  
6035     for a real number :math:`x`. 
6036  
6037     %(after_notes)s 
6038  
6039     %(example)s 
6040  
6041     """
6042     def _shape_info(self):
6043         return []
6044 
6045     def _rvs(self, size=None, random_state=None):
6046         return random_state.laplace(0, 1, size=size)
6047 
6048     def _pdf(self, x):
6049         # laplace.pdf(x) = 1/2 * exp(-abs(x))
6050         return 0.5*np.exp(-abs(x))
6051 
6052     def _cdf(self, x):
6053         with np.errstate(over='ignore'):
6054             return np.where(x > 0, 1.0 - 0.5*np.exp(-x), 0.5*np.exp(x))
6055 
6056     def _sf(self, x):
6057         # By symmetry...
6058         return self._cdf(-x)
6059 
6060     def _ppf(self, q):
6061         return np.where(q > 0.5, -np.log(2*(1-q)), np.log(2*q))
6062 
6063     def _isf(self, q):
6064         # By symmetry...
6065         return -self._ppf(q)
6066 
6067     def _stats(self):
6068         return 0, 2, 0, 3
6069 
6070     def _entropy(self):
6071         return np.log(2)+1
6072 
6073     @_call_super_mom
6074     @replace_notes_in_docstring(rv_continuous, notes="""\ 
6075         This function uses explicit formulas for the maximum likelihood 
6076         estimation of the Laplace distribution parameters, so the keyword 
6077         arguments `loc`, `scale`, and `optimizer` are ignored.\n\n""")
6078     def fit(self, data, *args, **kwds):
6079         data, floc, fscale = _check_fit_input_parameters(self, data,
6080                                                          args, kwds)
6081 
6082         # Source: Statistical Distributions, 3rd Edition. Evans, Hastings,
6083         # and Peacock (2000), Page 124
6084 
6085         if floc is None:
6086             floc = np.median(data)
6087 
6088         if fscale is None:
6089             fscale = (np.sum(np.abs(data - floc))) / len(data)
6090 
6091         return floc, fscale
6092 
6093 
6094 laplace = laplace_gen(name='laplace')
6095 
6096 
6097 class laplace_asymmetric_gen(rv_continuous):
6098     r"""An asymmetric Laplace continuous random variable. 
6099  
6100     %(before_notes)s 
6101  
6102     See Also 
6103     -------- 
6104     laplace : Laplace distribution 
6105  
6106     Notes 
6107     ----- 
6108     The probability density function for `laplace_asymmetric` is 
6109  
6110     .. math:: 
6111  
6112        f(x, \kappa) &= \frac{1}{\kappa+\kappa^{-1}}\exp(-x\kappa),\quad x\ge0\\ 
6113                     &= \frac{1}{\kappa+\kappa^{-1}}\exp(x/\kappa),\quad x<0\\ 
6114  
6115     for :math:`-\infty < x < \infty`, :math:`\kappa > 0`. 
6116  
6117     `laplace_asymmetric` takes ``kappa`` as a shape parameter for 
6118     :math:`\kappa`. For :math:`\kappa = 1`, it is identical to a 
6119     Laplace distribution. 
6120  
6121     %(after_notes)s 
6122  
6123     Note that the scale parameter of some references is the reciprocal of 
6124     SciPy's ``scale``. For example, :math:`\lambda = 1/2` in the 
6125     parameterization of [1]_ is equivalent to ``scale = 2`` with 
6126     `laplace_asymmetric`. 
6127  
6128     References 
6129     ---------- 
6130     .. [1] "Asymmetric Laplace distribution", Wikipedia 
6131             https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asymmetric_Laplace_distribution 
6132  
6133     .. [2] Kozubowski TJ and Podgrski K. A Multivariate and 
6134            Asymmetric Generalization of Laplace Distribution, 
6135            Computational Statistics 15, 531--540 (2000). 
6136            :doi:`10.1007/PL00022717` 
6137  
6138     %(example)s 
6139  
6140     """
6141     def _shape_info(self):
6142         return [_ShapeInfo("kappa", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))]
6143 
6144     def _pdf(self, x, kappa):
6145         return np.exp(self._logpdf(x, kappa))
6146 
6147     def _logpdf(self, x, kappa):
6148         kapinv = 1/kappa
6149         lPx = x * np.where(x >= 0, -kappa, kapinv)
6150         lPx -= np.log(kappa+kapinv)
6151         return lPx
6152 
6153     def _cdf(self, x, kappa):
6154         kapinv = 1/kappa
6155         kappkapinv = kappa+kapinv
6156         return np.where(x >= 0,
6157                         1 - np.exp(-x*kappa)*(kapinv/kappkapinv),
6158                         np.exp(x*kapinv)*(kappa/kappkapinv))
6159 
6160     def _sf(self, x, kappa):
6161         kapinv = 1/kappa
6162         kappkapinv = kappa+kapinv
6163         return np.where(x >= 0,
6164                         np.exp(-x*kappa)*(kapinv/kappkapinv),
6165                         1 - np.exp(x*kapinv)*(kappa/kappkapinv))
6166 
6167     def _ppf(self, q, kappa):
6168         kapinv = 1/kappa
6169         kappkapinv = kappa+kapinv
6170         return np.where(q >= kappa/kappkapinv,
6171                         -np.log((1 - q)*kappkapinv*kappa)*kapinv,
6172                         np.log(q*kappkapinv/kappa)*kappa)
6173 
6174     def _isf(self, q, kappa):
6175         kapinv = 1/kappa
6176         kappkapinv = kappa+kapinv
6177         return np.where(q <= kapinv/kappkapinv,
6178                         -np.log(q*kappkapinv*kappa)*kapinv,
6179                         np.log((1 - q)*kappkapinv/kappa)*kappa)
6180 
6181     def _stats(self, kappa):
6182         kapinv = 1/kappa
6183         mn = kapinv - kappa
6184         var = kapinv*kapinv + kappa*kappa
6185         g1 = 2.0*(1-np.power(kappa, 6))/np.power(1+np.power(kappa, 4), 1.5)
6186         g2 = 6.0*(1+np.power(kappa, 8))/np.power(1+np.power(kappa, 4), 2)
6187         return mn, var, g1, g2
6188 
6189     def _entropy(self, kappa):
6190         return 1 + np.log(kappa+1/kappa)
6191 
6192 
6193 laplace_asymmetric = laplace_asymmetric_gen(name='laplace_asymmetric')
6194 
6195 
6196 def _check_fit_input_parameters(dist, data, args, kwds):
6197     if not isinstance(data, CensoredData):
6198         data = np.asarray(data)
6199 
6200     floc = kwds.get('floc', None)
6201     fscale = kwds.get('fscale', None)
6202 
6203     num_shapes = len(dist.shapes.split(",")) if dist.shapes else 0
6204     fshape_keys = []
6205     fshapes = []
6206 
6207     # user has many options for fixing the shape, so here we standardize it
6208     # into 'f' + the number of the shape.
6209     # Adapted from `_reduce_func` in `_distn_infrastructure.py`:
6210     if dist.shapes:
6211         shapes = dist.shapes.replace(',', ' ').split()
6212         for j, s in enumerate(shapes):
6213             key = 'f' + str(j)
6214             names = [key, 'f' + s, 'fix_' + s]
6215             val = _get_fixed_fit_value(kwds, names)
6216             fshape_keys.append(key)
6217             fshapes.append(val)
6218             if val is not None:
6219                 kwds[key] = val
6220 
6221     # determine if there are any unknown arguments in kwds
6222     known_keys = {'loc', 'scale', 'optimizer', 'method',
6223                   'floc', 'fscale', *fshape_keys}
6224     unknown_keys = set(kwds).difference(known_keys)
6225     if unknown_keys:
6226         raise TypeError(f"Unknown keyword arguments: {unknown_keys}.")
6227 
6228     if len(args) > num_shapes:
6229         raise TypeError("Too many positional arguments.")
6230 
6231     if None not in {floc, fscale, *fshapes}:
6232         # This check is for consistency with `rv_continuous.fit`.
6233         # Without this check, this function would just return the
6234         # parameters that were given.
6235         raise RuntimeError("All parameters fixed. There is nothing to "
6236                            "optimize.")
6237 
6238     uncensored = data._uncensor() if isinstance(data, CensoredData) else data
6239     if not np.isfinite(uncensored).all():
6240         raise ValueError("The data contains non-finite values.")
6241 
6242     return (data, *fshapes, floc, fscale)
6243 
6244 
6245 class levy_gen(rv_continuous):
6246     r"""A Levy continuous random variable. 
6247  
6248     %(before_notes)s 
6249  
6250     See Also 
6251     -------- 
6252     levy_stable, levy_l 
6253  
6254     Notes 
6255     ----- 
6256     The probability density function for `levy` is: 
6257  
6258     .. math:: 
6259  
6260         f(x) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi x^3}} \exp\left(-\frac{1}{2x}\right) 
6261  
6262     for :math:`x > 0`. 
6263  
6264     This is the same as the Levy-stable distribution with :math:`a=1/2` and 
6265     :math:`b=1`. 
6266  
6267     %(after_notes)s 
6268  
6269     Examples 
6270     -------- 
6271     >>> import numpy as np 
6272     >>> from scipy.stats import levy 
6273     >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt 
6274     >>> fig, ax = plt.subplots(1, 1) 
6275  
6276     Calculate the first four moments: 
6277  
6278     >>> mean, var, skew, kurt = levy.stats(moments='mvsk') 
6279  
6280     Display the probability density function (``pdf``): 
6281  
6282     >>> # `levy` is very heavy-tailed. 
6283     >>> # To show a nice plot, let's cut off the upper 40 percent. 
6284     >>> a, b = levy.ppf(0), levy.ppf(0.6) 
6285     >>> x = np.linspace(a, b, 100) 
6286     >>> ax.plot(x, levy.pdf(x), 
6287     ...        'r-', lw=5, alpha=0.6, label='levy pdf') 
6288  
6289     Alternatively, the distribution object can be called (as a function) 
6290     to fix the shape, location and scale parameters. This returns a "frozen" 
6291     RV object holding the given parameters fixed. 
6292  
6293     Freeze the distribution and display the frozen ``pdf``: 
6294  
6295     >>> rv = levy() 
6296     >>> ax.plot(x, rv.pdf(x), 'k-', lw=2, label='frozen pdf') 
6297  
6298     Check accuracy of ``cdf`` and ``ppf``: 
6299  
6300     >>> vals = levy.ppf([0.001, 0.5, 0.999]) 
6301     >>> np.allclose([0.001, 0.5, 0.999], levy.cdf(vals)) 
6302     True 
6303  
6304     Generate random numbers: 
6305  
6306     >>> r = levy.rvs(size=1000) 
6307  
6308     And compare the histogram: 
6309  
6310     >>> # manual binning to ignore the tail 
6311     >>> bins = np.concatenate((np.linspace(a, b, 20), [np.max(r)])) 
6312     >>> ax.hist(r, bins=bins, density=True, histtype='stepfilled', alpha=0.2) 
6313     >>> ax.set_xlim([x[0], x[-1]]) 
6314     >>> ax.legend(loc='best', frameon=False) 
6315     >>> plt.show() 
6316  
6317     """
6318     _support_mask = rv_continuous._open_support_mask
6319 
6320     def _shape_info(self):
6321         return []
6322 
6323     def _pdf(self, x):
6324         # levy.pdf(x) = 1 / (x * sqrt(2*pi*x)) * exp(-1/(2*x))
6325         return 1 / np.sqrt(2*np.pi*x) / x * np.exp(-1/(2*x))
6326 
6327     def _cdf(self, x):
6328         # Equivalent to 2*norm.sf(np.sqrt(1/x))
6329         return sc.erfc(np.sqrt(0.5 / x))
6330 
6331     def _sf(self, x):
6332         return sc.erf(np.sqrt(0.5 / x))
6333 
6334     def _ppf(self, q):
6335         # Equivalent to 1.0/(norm.isf(q/2)**2) or 0.5/(erfcinv(q)**2)
6336         val = _norm_isf(q/2)
6337         return 1.0 / (val * val)
6338 
6339     def _isf(self, p):
6340         return 1/(2*sc.erfinv(p)**2)
6341 
6342     def _stats(self):
6343         return np.inf, np.inf, np.nan, np.nan
6344 
6345 
6346 levy = levy_gen(a=0.0, name="levy")
6347 
6348 
6349 class levy_l_gen(rv_continuous):
6350     r"""A left-skewed Levy continuous random variable. 
6351  
6352     %(before_notes)s 
6353  
6354     See Also 
6355     -------- 
6356     levy, levy_stable 
6357  
6358     Notes 
6359     ----- 
6360     The probability density function for `levy_l` is: 
6361  
6362     .. math:: 
6363         f(x) = \frac{1}{|x| \sqrt{2\pi |x|}} \exp{ \left(-\frac{1}{2|x|} \right)} 
6364  
6365     for :math:`x < 0`. 
6366  
6367     This is the same as the Levy-stable distribution with :math:`a=1/2` and 
6368     :math:`b=-1`. 
6369  
6370     %(after_notes)s 
6371  
6372     Examples 
6373     -------- 
6374     >>> import numpy as np 
6375     >>> from scipy.stats import levy_l 
6376     >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt 
6377     >>> fig, ax = plt.subplots(1, 1) 
6378  
6379     Calculate the first four moments: 
6380  
6381     >>> mean, var, skew, kurt = levy_l.stats(moments='mvsk') 
6382  
6383     Display the probability density function (``pdf``): 
6384  
6385     >>> # `levy_l` is very heavy-tailed. 
6386     >>> # To show a nice plot, let's cut off the lower 40 percent. 
6387     >>> a, b = levy_l.ppf(0.4), levy_l.ppf(1) 
6388     >>> x = np.linspace(a, b, 100) 
6389     >>> ax.plot(x, levy_l.pdf(x), 
6390     ...        'r-', lw=5, alpha=0.6, label='levy_l pdf') 
6391  
6392     Alternatively, the distribution object can be called (as a function) 
6393     to fix the shape, location and scale parameters. This returns a "frozen" 
6394     RV object holding the given parameters fixed. 
6395  
6396     Freeze the distribution and display the frozen ``pdf``: 
6397  
6398     >>> rv = levy_l() 
6399     >>> ax.plot(x, rv.pdf(x), 'k-', lw=2, label='frozen pdf') 
6400  
6401     Check accuracy of ``cdf`` and ``ppf``: 
6402  
6403     >>> vals = levy_l.ppf([0.001, 0.5, 0.999]) 
6404     >>> np.allclose([0.001, 0.5, 0.999], levy_l.cdf(vals)) 
6405     True 
6406  
6407     Generate random numbers: 
6408  
6409     >>> r = levy_l.rvs(size=1000) 
6410  
6411     And compare the histogram: 
6412  
6413     >>> # manual binning to ignore the tail 
6414     >>> bins = np.concatenate(([np.min(r)], np.linspace(a, b, 20))) 
6415     >>> ax.hist(r, bins=bins, density=True, histtype='stepfilled', alpha=0.2) 
6416     >>> ax.set_xlim([x[0], x[-1]]) 
6417     >>> ax.legend(loc='best', frameon=False) 
6418     >>> plt.show() 
6419  
6420     """
6421     _support_mask = rv_continuous._open_support_mask
6422 
6423     def _shape_info(self):
6424         return []
6425 
6426     def _pdf(self, x):
6427         # levy_l.pdf(x) = 1 / (abs(x) * sqrt(2*pi*abs(x))) * exp(-1/(2*abs(x)))
6428         ax = abs(x)
6429         return 1/np.sqrt(2*np.pi*ax)/ax*np.exp(-1/(2*ax))
6430 
6431     def _cdf(self, x):
6432         ax = abs(x)
6433         return 2 * _norm_cdf(1 / np.sqrt(ax)) - 1
6434 
6435     def _sf(self, x):
6436         ax = abs(x)
6437         return 2 * _norm_sf(1 / np.sqrt(ax))
6438 
6439     def _ppf(self, q):
6440         val = _norm_ppf((q + 1.0) / 2)
6441         return -1.0 / (val * val)
6442 
6443     def _isf(self, p):
6444         return -1/_norm_isf(p/2)**2
6445 
6446     def _stats(self):
6447         return np.inf, np.inf, np.nan, np.nan
6448 
6449 
6450 levy_l = levy_l_gen(b=0.0, name="levy_l")
6451 
6452 
6453 class logistic_gen(rv_continuous):
6454     r"""A logistic (or Sech-squared) continuous random variable. 
6455  
6456     %(before_notes)s 
6457  
6458     Notes 
6459     ----- 
6460     The probability density function for `logistic` is: 
6461  
6462     .. math:: 
6463  
6464         f(x) = \frac{\exp(-x)} 
6465                     {(1+\exp(-x))^2} 
6466  
6467     `logistic` is a special case of `genlogistic` with ``c=1``. 
6468  
6469     Remark that the survival function (``logistic.sf``) is equal to the 
6470     Fermi-Dirac distribution describing fermionic statistics. 
6471  
6472     %(after_notes)s 
6473  
6474     %(example)s 
6475  
6476     """
6477     def _shape_info(self):
6478         return []
6479 
6480     def _rvs(self, size=None, random_state=None):
6481         return random_state.logistic(size=size)
6482 
6483     def _pdf(self, x):
6484         # logistic.pdf(x) = exp(-x) / (1+exp(-x))**2
6485         return np.exp(self._logpdf(x))
6486 
6487     def _logpdf(self, x):
6488         y = -np.abs(x)
6489         return y - 2. * sc.log1p(np.exp(y))
6490 
6491     def _cdf(self, x):
6492         return sc.expit(x)
6493 
6494     def _logcdf(self, x):
6495         return sc.log_expit(x)
6496 
6497     def _ppf(self, q):
6498         return sc.logit(q)
6499 
6500     def _sf(self, x):
6501         return sc.expit(-x)
6502 
6503     def _logsf(self, x):
6504         return sc.log_expit(-x)
6505 
6506     def _isf(self, q):
6507         return -sc.logit(q)
6508 
6509     def _stats(self):
6510         return 0, np.pi*np.pi/3.0, 0, 6.0/5.0
6511 
6512     def _entropy(self):
6513         # https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logistic_distribution
6514         return 2.0
6515 
6516     @_call_super_mom
6517     @inherit_docstring_from(rv_continuous)
6518     def fit(self, data, *args, **kwds):
6519         if kwds.pop('superfit', False):
6520             return super().fit(data, *args, **kwds)
6521 
6522         data, floc, fscale = _check_fit_input_parameters(self, data,
6523                                                          args, kwds)
6524         n = len(data)
6525 
6526         # rv_continuous provided guesses
6527         loc, scale = self._fitstart(data)
6528         # these are trumped by user-provided guesses
6529         loc, scale = kwds.get('loc', loc), kwds.get('scale', scale)
6530 
6531         # the maximum likelihood estimators `a` and `b` of the location and
6532         # scale parameters are roots of the two equations described in `func`.
6533         # Source: Statistical Distributions, 3rd Edition. Evans, Hastings, and
6534         # Peacock (2000), Page 130
6535 
6536         def dl_dloc(loc, scale=fscale):
6537             c = (data - loc) / scale
6538             return np.sum(sc.expit(c)) - n/2
6539 
6540         def dl_dscale(scale, loc=floc):
6541             c = (data - loc) / scale
6542             return np.sum(c*np.tanh(c/2)) - n
6543 
6544         def func(params):
6545             loc, scale = params
6546             return dl_dloc(loc, scale), dl_dscale(scale, loc)
6547 
6548         if fscale is not None and floc is None:
6549             res = optimize.root(dl_dloc, (loc,))
6550             loc = res.x[0]
6551             scale = fscale
6552         elif floc is not None and fscale is None:
6553             res = optimize.root(dl_dscale, (scale,))
6554             scale = res.x[0]
6555             loc = floc
6556         else:
6557             res = optimize.root(func, (loc, scale))
6558             loc, scale = res.x
6559 
6560         # Note: gh-18176 reported data for which the reported MLE had
6561         # `scale < 0`. To fix the bug, we return abs(scale). This is OK because
6562         # `dl_dscale` and `dl_dloc` are even and odd functions of `scale`,
6563         # respectively, so if `-scale` is a solution, so is `scale`.
6564         scale = abs(scale)
6565         return ((loc, scale) if res.success
6566                 else super().fit(data, *args, **kwds))
6567 
6568 
6569 logistic = logistic_gen(name='logistic')
6570 
6571 
6572 class loggamma_gen(rv_continuous):
6573     r"""A log gamma continuous random variable. 
6574  
6575     %(before_notes)s 
6576  
6577     Notes 
6578     ----- 
6579     The probability density function for `loggamma` is: 
6580  
6581     .. math:: 
6582  
6583         f(x, c) = \frac{\exp(c x - \exp(x))} 
6584                        {\Gamma(c)} 
6585  
6586     for all :math:`x, c > 0`. Here, :math:`\Gamma` is the 
6587     gamma function (`scipy.special.gamma`). 
6588  
6589     `loggamma` takes ``c`` as a shape parameter for :math:`c`. 
6590  
6591     %(after_notes)s 
6592  
6593     %(example)s 
6594  
6595     """
6596 
6597     def _shape_info(self):
6598         return [_ShapeInfo("c", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))]
6599 
6600     def _rvs(self, c, size=None, random_state=None):
6601         # Use the property of the gamma distribution Gamma(c)
6602         #    Gamma(c) ~ Gamma(c + 1)*U**(1/c),
6603         # where U is uniform on [0, 1]. (See, e.g.,
6604         # G. Marsaglia and W.W. Tsang, "A simple method for generating gamma
6605         # variables", https://doi.org/10.1145/358407.358414)
6606         # So
6607         #    log(Gamma(c)) ~ log(Gamma(c + 1)) + log(U)/c
6608         # Generating a sample with this formulation is a bit slower
6609         # than the more obvious log(Gamma(c)), but it avoids loss
6610         # of precision when c << 1.
6611         return (np.log(random_state.gamma(c + 1, size=size))
6612                 + np.log(random_state.uniform(size=size))/c)
6613 
6614     def _pdf(self, x, c):
6615         # loggamma.pdf(x, c) = exp(c*x-exp(x)) / gamma(c)
6616         return np.exp(c*x-np.exp(x)-sc.gammaln(c))
6617 
6618     def _logpdf(self, x, c):
6619         return c*x - np.exp(x) - sc.gammaln(c)
6620 
6621     def _cdf(self, x, c):
6622         # This function is gammainc(c, exp(x)), where gammainc(c, z) is
6623         # the regularized incomplete gamma function.
6624         # The first term in a series expansion of gamminc(c, z) is
6625         # z**c/Gamma(c+1); see 6.5.29 of Abramowitz & Stegun (and refer
6626         # back to 6.5.1, 6.5.2 and 6.5.4 for the relevant notation).
6627         # This can also be found in the wikipedia article
6628         # https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Incomplete_gamma_function.
6629         # Here we use that formula when x is sufficiently negative that
6630         # exp(x) will result in subnormal numbers and lose precision.
6631         # We evaluate the log of the expression first to allow the possible
6632         # cancellation of the terms in the division, and then exponentiate.
6633         # That is,
6634         #     exp(x)**c/Gamma(c+1) = exp(log(exp(x)**c/Gamma(c+1)))
6635         #                          = exp(c*x - gammaln(c+1))
6636         return _lazywhere(x < _LOGXMIN, (x, c),
6637                           lambda x, c: np.exp(c*x - sc.gammaln(c+1)),
6638                           f2=lambda x, c: sc.gammainc(c, np.exp(x)))
6639 
6640     def _ppf(self, q, c):
6641         # The expression used when g < _XMIN inverts the one term expansion
6642         # given in the comments of _cdf().
6643         g = sc.gammaincinv(c, q)
6644         return _lazywhere(g < _XMIN, (g, q, c),
6645                           lambda g, q, c: (np.log(q) + sc.gammaln(c+1))/c,
6646                           f2=lambda g, q, c: np.log(g))
6647 
6648     def _sf(self, x, c):
6649         # See the comments for _cdf() for how x < _LOGXMIN is handled.
6650         return _lazywhere(x < _LOGXMIN, (x, c),
6651                           lambda x, c: -np.expm1(c*x - sc.gammaln(c+1)),
6652                           f2=lambda x, c: sc.gammaincc(c, np.exp(x)))
6653 
6654     def _isf(self, q, c):
